#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Be a Successful Pilgrim
#Text=Travelling for a religious purpose to a pilgrim town is very different from a summer holiday with family or backpacking with friends .
#Text=These steps will help you become a successful pilgrim .
#Text=Please note that " temple " is used as a generic term , but you could well substitute it with churche/mosque/synagogue or any other place of worship .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Feel as if God wants you to undertake this journey and remain eager to see the temple .
#Text=Slowly , bring the shrine and the particular deity into your consciousness , right from the time you get the idea to go on the trip .
#Text=Search the net for articles and experiences of people who visited the same place and your urge to make it happen will become stronger .
#Text=As that happens , the Universe will pave the way for you to reach your destination , and all the details will fall into place .
#Text=Book a flight after checking the timings of the place of worship .
#Text=If a temple is closed between 1 . p. m. and 4p . m. ,you would not want a flight which arrives during those hours .
#Text=Most pilgrim spots are small towns which have little to offer in terms of entertainment , so long hours of waiting could bring on serious boredom .
#Text=For the same reason , keep your trip short and try to take the return flight as soon as you finish your visit to the shrine(s) .
#Text=Book a hotel room if you find you need to stay more than a day .
#Text=Choose wisely- remember you are visiting a holy town for a day or two , you do n't really need a swimming pool and a spa during that period .
#Text=Do n't make luxury a priority and pay for facilities you might never use .
#Text=Instead choose a hotel that offers acceptable levels of comfort and is located close to the temple .
#Text=If your hotel offers transfers from and to the airport , you 're lucky .
#Text=Otherwise , hop onto a local taxi or bus which will take you to your hotel .
#Text=Choose a mode of transport that has been approved by a local government body .
#Text=That way , you have less chances of getting ripped off by touts who abound in pilgrim spots .
#Text=Be prepared to withstand physical strain .
#Text=Some places require climbing several flights of stairs or long hours of walking or standing in queues .
#Text=Safeguard your money .
#Text=The road to temples is often lined with shops selling flowers , candles , lamps , holy threads , cloth pieces of holy colours , food items special to the place , etc.
#Text=The shopkeepers often hound pilgrims into buying them and make it appear as though your trip will be meaningless without these offerings .
#Text=Do not feel obliged or get talked into buying anything .
#Text=Only buy if you feel convinced that you must follow the custom .
#Text=Sometimes , managing all the paraphernalia in your hands can be distracting while you worship-so think before you buy .
#Text=Be aware about technology .
#Text=Many temples prohibit the use of mobile phones and cameras .
#Text=You will be asked to deposit your gadgets at a special counter at the entrance , ( sometimes for a fee ) that many temples have , and collect them later .
#Text=Get in the right mood .
#Text=At least 10 minutes before you reach the main spot , avoid chatting or laughing with those around and make an effort to quiet yourself inside .
#Text=Focus your energies on God and the reason you are there .
#Text=If you know any prayers or chants , repeat them to yourself .
#Text=Buy yourself a souvenir or a book that narrates the legend of the town and the deity , to share with folks back home .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Be culturally sensitive .
#Text=Some temples prohibit leather , some do n't allow entry to foreigners inside the main sanctuary .
#Text=Rather than argue with the local authorities after reaching there , be informed of these restrictions before and act accordingly .
#Text=While temples and mosques can be noisy , churches have a hushed silence inside and it would be disturbing to others if you are strolling around with a bawling infant or talking on your mobile .
#Text=Dress sensibly according to the religious customs of the place .
#Text=Avoid exposed limbs , which might be considered objectionable in some places .
#Text=In general it is better to err on the conservative side .
#Text=If you are a woman , now is not the time for deeply cut blouses or extra tight T- shirts or jeans .
#Text=The reason there is a dress code for holy places is so that pilgrims are not distracted and are able to concentrate on their worship .
#Text=Some holy places require one 's head to be covered with a scarf .
#Text=Also dress according to the temperature and whether the trip requires any climbing of hills or walking for a long time .
#Text=Conduct yourself in a way in which you do n't offend the sensibilities of other devotees and violate local norms .
#Text=Be patient in long queues .
#Text=Do n't jostle and push your way around .
#Text=Everyone is equal in the eyes of God and there 's no reason you should be allowed first .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Beware of touts and anyone who promises to get you any kind of deal .
#Text=They are likely to be frauds .
#Text=This is especially so if you are a foreigner to that country and visually seem like one .
#Text=In many Hindu temples in India , people of other religions are not allowed into the main shrine .
#Text=However , you must n't be disappointed as there is enough architectural splendour in the rest of the temple to keep you clicking away and ask the guide a zillion questions .
#Text=If you are asthmatic or diabetic or have any medical condition that may need emergency aid , keep the relevant supplies handy .
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=Faith in God
#Text=Internet bookings
#Text=Sensible clothes
